mlp

Class LexiconFactory

  • java.lang.Object
    • mlp.LexiconFactory

  • public class LexiconFactory
extends java.lang.Object
    A factory class with static methods to create Lexicon objects from input files, write Lexicons into files, merge Lexicons, change the names of features and the names of feature-sets, and provides some other Lexicon related methods.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructor and Description
      LexiconFactory()

    • Method Detail

      • createLexicon

        public static Lexicon createLexicon(java.lang.String filename,
                                    java.lang.String entrySignal,
                                    java.lang.String featureSetSignal,
                                    java.lang.String lineElementSignal,
                                    java.lang.String inlineElementSep)
                             throws java.io.IOException
        Reads the contents of the lexicon stored in the specified file, and creates and returns a Lexicon object.

        Each lexicon entry is one key with one or more associated feature sets. Each key must be on a separate line, and must be signaled by the specified entrySignal that must occur at the start of the line, ignoring leading spaces.

        The feature sets are alternative semantics/features of the key. Collectively, the feature sets are called the "body" of the lexicon entry. Each feature set starts on a new separate line, and must be signaled by the specified featureSetSignal that must occur at the start of a line, ignoring leading spaces. The body of a feature set is a sequence of features, where each feature is a name-value pair. A feature name must occur at the start of a new line, ignoring leading spaces, and must end with a colon. The feature value can be in one of two formats:

        1. a single string which follows the colon that comes after the feature name, and extends until the end of the line. That string can conceptually be a sequence of many value-elements, separated by a specified inlineElementSep, such as a semicolon or a vertical bar.
        2. a sequence of lines that come after the line that has the feature name. That sequence is then a sequence of value-elements, each of which must start on a new line, and must be signaled by the specified lineElementSignal, which can be a hyphen followed by a space, a star, a plus, etc.

        Note that when the value elements of a feature are on succeeding line(s), the feature name is appended with "//" to signal this case. Note also that entrySignal, featureSetSignal, and lineElementSignal must be reserved keywords that, whenever any of them occurs at the start of a new line, signals the start of a new lexicon entry, a feature set, or a value-element, respectively. But if embedded within a line (with preceding non-spaces), then they are not treated as a reserved keywords and thus do not signal anything.
        Parameters:
        filename - the name of the file containing the lexicon
        entrySignal - a string/pattern that signals the start of a new lexicon entry.
        featureSetSignal - a string/pattern that signals the start of a new feature set of a lexicon entry.
        lineElementSignal - a string/pattern that signals the start of a new value-element of a feature, when the value elements are lines that follow the line having the feature name.
        inlineElementSep - the inlineElementSep that separates the various value elements of a feature, when those elements occur together on the same line after the feature name and colon.
        Returns:
        a map whose keys are the lexicon keys, and the value of every key is a list of the feature sets making up the body of the corresponding lexicon entry, where every feature set is modeled by a FeatureSet object.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if the file could not be found or read

      • createLexicon

        public static Lexicon createLexicon(java.nio.file.Path path,
                                    java.lang.String entrySignal,
                                    java.lang.String featureSetSignal,
                                    java.lang.String lineElementSignal,
                                    java.lang.String inlineElementSep)
                             throws java.io.IOException
        Like other createLexicon() except that the lexicon is in the specified path.
        Parameters:
        path - the Path of the file containing the lexicon
        entrySignal - a string/pattern that signals the start of a new lexicon entry.
        featureSetSignal - a string/pattern that signals the start of a new feature set of a lexicon entry.
        lineElementSignal - a string/pattern that signals the start of a new value-element of a feature, when the value elements are lines that follow the line having the feature name.
        inlineElementSep - the inlineElementSep that separates the various value elements of a feature, when those elements occur together on the same line after the feature name and colon.
        Returns:
        a map whose keys are the lexicon keys, and the value of every key is a list of the feature sets making up the body of the corresponding lexicon entry, where every feature set is modeled by a FeatureSet object.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if the file could not be found or read

      • createLexicon

        public static Lexicon createLexicon(java.lang.String filename,
                                    java.lang.String entrySignal,
                                    java.lang.String featureSetSignal,
                                    java.lang.String lineElementSignal,
                                    java.lang.String inlineElementSep,
                                    java.lang.String entrySignalEnd)
                             throws java.io.IOException
        Like other createLexicon() except this time each lexicon entry key ends (on the same line) with the specified entrySignalEnd.
        Parameters:
        filename - the name of the file containing the lexicon
        entrySignal - a string/pattern that signals the start of a new lexicon entry.
        featureSetSignal - a string/pattern that signals the start of a new feature set of a lexicon entry.
        lineElementSignal - a string/pattern that signals the start of a new value-element of a feature, when the value elements are lines that follow the line having the feature name.
        inlineElementSep - the inlineElementSep that separates the various value elements of a feature, when those elements occur together on the same line after the feature name and colon.
        entrySignalEnd - a string that marks the end of the lexicon entry key in the same line that has an entry key.
        Returns:
        a map whose keys are the lexicon keys, and the value of every key is a list of the feature sets making up the body of the corresponding lexicon entry, where every feature set is modeled by a FeatureSet object.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if the file could not be found or read

        entrySignalEnd - a string that marks the end of the lexicon entry key in the same line that has an entry key.
        Returns:
        a map whose keys are the lexicon keys, and the value of every key is a list of the feature sets making up the body of the corresponding lexicon entry, where every feature set is modeled by a FeatureSet object.

        java.io.IOException - if the file could not be found or read

      • createLexiconMap

        public static java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.util.List<FeatureSet>> createLexiconMap(java.nio.file.Path path,
                                                                                          java.lang.String entrySignal,
                                                                                          java.lang.String featureSetSignal,
                                                                                          java.lang.String lineElementSignal,
                                                                                          java.lang.String inlineElementSep)
                                                                                   throws java.io.IOException
        Reads the contents of the lexicon stored in the file specified by the Path argument, and creates and returns a map, which has one map entry per lexicon entry. Each lexicon entry is one key with one or more associated feature sets. Each key must be on a separate line, and must be signaled by the specified entrySignal that must occur at the start of the line, ignoring leading spaces. The feature sets are alternative semantics/features of the key. Collectively, the feature sets are called the "body" of the lexicon entry. Each feature set starts on a new separate line, and must be signaled by the specified featureSetSignal that must occur at the start of a line, ignoring leading spaces. The body of a feature set is a sequence of features, where each feature is a name-value pair. A feature name must occur at the start of a new line, ignoring leading spaces, and must end with a colon. The feature value can be in one of two formats:
        1. a single string which follows the colon that comes after the feature name, and extends until the end of the line. That string can conceptually be a sequence of many value-elements, separated by a specified inlineElementSep, such as a semicolon or a vertical bar.
        2. a sequence of lines that come after the line that has the feature name. That sequence is then a sequence of value-elements, each of which must start on a new line, and must be signaled by the specified lineElementSignal, which can be a hyphen followed by a space, a star, a plus, etc.

        Note that when the value elements of a feature are on succeeding line(s), the feature name is appended with "//" to signal this case. Note also that entrySignal, featureSetSignal, and lineElementSignal must be reserved keywords that, whenever any of them occurs at the start of a new line, signals the start of a new lexicon entry, a feature set, or a value-element, respectively. But if embedded within a line (with preceding non-spaces), then they are not treated as a reserved keywords and thus do not signal anything.
        Parameters:
        path - the Path of the file containing the lexicon
        entrySignal - a string/pattern that signals the start of a new lexicon entry.
        featureSetSignal - a string/pattern that signals the start of a new feature set of a lexicon entry.
        lineElementSignal - a string/pattern that signals the start of a new value-element of a feature, when the value elements are lines that follow the line having the feature name.
        inlineElementSep - the inlineElementSep that separates the various value elements of a feature, when those elements occur together on the same line after the feature name and colon.
        Returns:
        a map whose keys are the lexicon keys, and the value of every key is a list of the feature sets making up the body of the corresponding lexicon entry, where every feature set is modeled by a FeatureSet object.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if the file could not be found or read

      • createLexiconMap

        public static java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.util.List<FeatureSet>> createLexiconMap(java.lang.String[] lines,
                                                                                          java.lang.String entrySignal,
                                                                                          java.lang.String featureSetSignal,
                                                                                          java.lang.String lineElementSignal,
                                                                                          java.lang.String inlineElementSep,
                                                                                          java.lang.String entrySignalEnd)
                                                                                   throws java.io.IOException
        Reads the contents of the lexicon represented by the specified lines array, and creates and returns a map, which has one map entry per lexicon entry. Each lexicon entry is one key with one or more associated feature sets. Each key must be on a separate line, and must be signaled by the specified entrySignal that must occur at the start of the line, ignoring leading spaces. The feature sets are alternative semantics/features of the key. Collectively, the feature sets are called the "body" of the lexicon entry. Each feature set starts on a new separate line, and must be signaled by the specified featureSetSignal that must occur at the start of a line, ignoring leading spaces. The body of a feature set is a sequence of features, where each feature is a name-value pair. A feature name must occur at the start of a new line, ignoring leading spaces, and must end with a colon. The feature value can be a in one of two formats:
        1. a single string which follows the colon that comes after the feature name, and extends until the end of the line. That string can conceptually be a sequence of many value-elements, separated by a specified inlineElementSep, such as a semicolon or a vertical bar.
        2. a sequence of lines that come after the line that has the feature name. That sequence is then a sequence of value-elements, each of which must start on a new line, and must be signaled by the specified lineElementSignal, which can be a hyphen followed by a space, a star, a plus, etc.

        Note that when the value elements of a feature are on succeeding line(s), the feature name is appended with "//" to signal this case. Note also that entrySignal, featureSetSignal, and lineElementSignal must be reserved keywords that, whenever any of them occurs at the start of a new line, signals the start of a new lexicon entry, a feature set, or a value-element, respectively. But if embedded within a line (with preceding non-spaces), then they are not treated as a reserved keywords and thus do not signal anything.
        Parameters:
        lines - the lines containing the lexicon
        entrySignal - a string/pattern that signals the start of a new lexicon entry.
        featureSetSignal - a string/pattern that signals the start of a new feature set of a lexicon entry.
        lineElementSignal - a string/pattern that signals the start of a new value-element of a feature, when the value elements are lines that follow the line having the feature name.
        inlineElementSep - the inlineElementSep that separates the various value elements of a feature, when those elements occur together on the same line after the feature name and colon.
        entrySignalEnd - a string that marks the end of the lexicon entry key in the same line that has an entry key.
        Returns:
        a map whose keys are the lexicon keys, and the value of every key is a list of the feature sets making up the body of the corresponding lexicon entry, where every feature set is modeled by a FeatureSet object.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if the file could not be found or read

      • getOrderedListOfEntryKeys

        public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> getOrderedListOfEntryKeys(java.nio.file.Path path,
                                                                         java.lang.String entryStartSignal,
                                                                         java.lang.String entryEndSignal)
                                                                  throws java.io.IOException
        Returns an ordered list of keys (String) from a specified lexicon of key-value entries, in the order in which they occur in the lexicon. If a key occurs in multiple locations, only the key's first location is returned.
        Parameters:
        path - the Path of the file containing a lexicon
        entryStartSignal - a string/pattern that signals the start of a new lexicon entry.
        entryEndSignal - a string that marks the end of the lexicon entry key in the same line that has an entry key.
        Returns:
        a list of the keys of the specified lexicon, in the same order as they occur in the lexicon. If a key occurs in multiple locations, only the first location is returned.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if the file could not be found or read

      • getOrderedListOfEntryKeys

        public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> getOrderedListOfEntryKeys(java.nio.file.Path path,
                                                                         java.lang.String entryStartSignal)
                                                                  throws java.io.IOException
        Returns an ordered list of keys (String) from a specified lexicon of key-value entries, in the order in which they occur in the lexicon. If a key occurs in multiple locations, only the key's first location is returned.
        Parameters:
        path - the Path of the file containing a lexicon
        entryStartSignal - a string/pattern that signals the start of a new lexicon entry.
        Returns:
        a list of the keys of the specified lexicon, in the same order as they occur in the lexicon. If a key occurs in multiple locations, only the first location is returned.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if the file could not be found or read

      • merge

        public static java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.util.List<FeatureSet>> merge(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.util.List<FeatureSet>> map1,
                                                                               java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.util.List<FeatureSet>> map2)
        Merges two input maps of lexicon entries and returns the merged outcome. If a term is a key in both maps, then their corresponding lists of feature sets are simply combined. No effort at eliminating feature-set redundancy or inconsistency is made.
        Parameters:
        map1 - the map of the first lexicon
        map2 - the map of the second lexicon
        Returns:
        the merged lexicon

      • mergeManyLexiconMaps

        public static java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.util.List<FeatureSet>> mergeManyLexiconMaps(java.lang.String entrySignal,
                                                                                              java.lang.String featureSetSignal,
                                                                                              java.lang.String lineElementSignal,
                                                                                              java.lang.String inlineElementSep,
                                                                                              java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.util.List<FeatureSet>> map1,
                                                                                              java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.util.List<FeatureSet>>... maps)
        Reads the specified files (as lexicon files) into lexicon maps, and merges those maps into a single lexicon map. If a term is a key in several maps, then their corresponding lists of feature sets are simply combined. No effort at eliminating feature-set redundancy or inconsistency is made.
        Parameters:
        entrySignal - the string that signals the start of a lexicon entry
        featureSetSignal - the string that signals the start of a feature set
        lineElementSignal - the string that signals the start, on a new line, of an alternative value-element of a feature.
        inlineElementSep - the string that separates inline alternative value-elements of a feature.
        map1 - the first lexicon map that is part of the merge
        maps - zero or more additional lexicon maps that are part of the merge
        Returns:
        a lexicon map that results from the merge.

      • mergeManyLexiconMaps

        public static java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.util.List<FeatureSet>> mergeManyLexiconMaps(java.lang.String entrySignal,
                                                                                              java.lang.String featureSetSignal,
                                                                                              java.lang.String lineElementSignal,
                                                                                              java.lang.String inlineElementSep,
                                                                                              java.lang.String file1,
                                                                                              java.lang.String... files)
        Reads the specified files (as lexicon files) into lexicon maps, and merges those maps into a single lexicon map.
        Parameters:
        entrySignal - the string that signals the start of a lexicon entry
        featureSetSignal - the string that signals the start of a feature set
        lineElementSignal - the string that signals the start, on a new line, of an alternative value-element of a feature.
        inlineElementSep - the string that separates inline alternative value-elements of a feature.
        file1 - the first lexicon file that is part of the merge
        files - zero or more additional lexicon files that are part of the merge
        Returns:
        a lexicon map that results from the merge.

      • outputLexiconMap

        public static void outputLexiconMap(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.util.List<FeatureSet>> map,
                                    java.lang.String symbolMarker,
                                    java.lang.String featureSetMarker,
                                    java.lang.String outfile,
                                    java.util.List<java.lang.String> orderedKeys,
                                    java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> oldToNewFeatureNames,
                                    java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> oldToNewFeatureSetNames)
        Outputs (into a file or onto the screen) the specified lexicon map. Each lexicon entry is preceded by the specified symbolMarker, and each feature set is preceded on a separate line by the specified featureSetMarker.
        Parameters:
        map - the lexicon map where each key is a lexicon entry name, and each value is a list of FeatureSet objects.
        symbolMarker - a string that will put right before each lexicon entry name in the output file
        featureSetMarker - a string that will be put on a separate line preceding each featureSet object
        outfile - the file in which the lexicon map will be stored. If null or empty, the output is printed on the screen.
        orderedKeys - a list (of entry-keys) according to whose order the entries of the specified lexicon will be output. If it is null or empty, then the lexicon is printed according to the order of the keyset of its map.
        oldToNewFeatureNames - a map whose keys are the feature-names to be changed, and the corresponding values are the new feature-names of those features. If it is null or empty, no changes are made to the feature names.
        oldToNewFeatureSetNames - a map whose keys are the Feature-Set names to be changed, and the corresponding values are the new names of those Feature-Sets. If it is null or empty, no changes are made to the feature-set names.

      • outputLexiconMap

        public static void outputLexiconMap(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.util.List<FeatureSet>> map,
                                    java.lang.String symbolMarker,
                                    java.lang.String featureSetMarker,
                                    java.lang.String outfile)
        Outputs (into a file or onto the screen) the specified lexicon map. Each lexicon entry is preceded by the specified symbolMarker, and each feature set is preceded on a separate line by the specified featureSetMarker.
        Parameters:
        map - the lexicon map where each key is a lexicon entry name, and each value is a list of FeatureSet objects.
        symbolMarker - a string that will put right before each lexicon entry name in the output file
        featureSetMarker - a string that will be put on a separate line preceding each FeatureSet object
        outfile - the file in which the lexicon map will be stored.

      • changeNames

        public static java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.util.List<FeatureSet>> changeNames(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.util.List<FeatureSet>> lexiconMap,
                                                                                     java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> oldToNewFeatureNames,
                                                                                     java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> oldToNewFeatureSetNames)
        In the specified lexicon map, this method changes the names of specified features to new names, and also changes the names of the specified Feature-Set names, and return the modified lexicon-map
        Parameters:
        lexiconMap - the input lexicon map
        oldToNewFeatureNames - a map whose keys are the names of the features to be changed, and the corresponding values are the new names of those features. If oldToNewFeatureNames is null or empty, no change is made to any feature names.
        oldToNewFeatureSetNames - a map whose keys are the Feature-Set names to be changed, and the corresponding values are the new names of those Feature-Sets. If it is null or empty, no changes are made to the feature-set names. If oldToNewFeatureSetNames is null or empty, no change is made to any feature-set names.
        Returns:
        the lexicon map after the changes have been made.
